+TheLeftLibertarianAtheist Yes. The idea is that an astronaut flies off at 
great velocity while his identical twin remains on Earth. His velocity 
results in time dilation so when the astronaut returns, more time has 
passed on Earth than he has experienced, resulting in his twin being older 
than him.

The paradox arises when we realize that not only does the twin on the Earth 
see time dilate for the astronaut, but the astronaut should see the same 
thing for his twin on Earth, and so would expect to be older than his twin 
when he returns, not the other way around.

The paradox is resolved when we take into account that the astronaut had to 
accelerate into order to achieve his great velocity, had to decelerate in 
order to slow down, accelerate again in the opposite direction, and then 
decelerate again once he returns. It's the acceleration and deceleration 
that causes him to actually be younger than his twin on Earth. This is a 
result of General Relativity, not Special Relativity.

Case 1. Traveler has passed through every moment of time. He has also been

Case 2. He has not passed through every moment, instead stepped over a 
couple, and hasn't been perceivable all the time.

If anyone goes into the past, he is, by definition, a time traveler, 
because he can't have passed through every moment, as the time flows 
towards the future, not towards the past.

Trust me, this distinction between the two cases may seem insignificant, 
but if you have studied physics, you should know that it is not. 

If you have two lines, the first one 10 cm and the other one 20 cm, which 
one has more individual points in it? The same goes with time. If you go 
from moment t1 to the moment t2, let's say that t2-t1 is 60 s (of the 
relative time of the observer), and your own time has only moved 15 s, have 
you had less individual moments? No. Please note that moment means a period 
of time which is infinitesimal.

The only difference is that the time of the object (referred to as "you") 
has flown to the final moment with greater velocity (and again, I'm not 
meaning velocity as v=s/t, but as relative velocity to the absolute 
space-time, in this case that I explained, it was by definition the same as 
the time of the observer). Is this what we think of as time travelling? 
Well, it is not. If this was time travelling, the whole point of the 
discussion becomes irrelevant, because then all existence would be time 
travelling.

Of course, this can't be the case. We don't travel through time, when we 
follow its natural flow (which, by the way, is defined by the growth of 
entropy. This causes some very interesting discussions about the reasons 
time slows down and stops inside the event horizon of a black hole, or when 
travelling at the speed of light). The time flows on independent of our 
actions. We exist in the absolute space-time. 

Think about two boats that share the exact same velocity v=s/t. Their 
distance from one another is x. The one closer to the shore is at the 
distance x from the shore. You stand at a point A on the shore. The both 
boats approach you from right, going to the left from your point of view. 
You measure a time t. In this period of time, the boat which is closer, 
appears to have covered a longer distance, of course. But, in fact, it has 
traveled exactly the same distance as the boat which is further. 

Pretty much the same way, if two objects have moved with different 
velocities, they appear to have traveled different periods of time. But 
when observed from the absolute space-time (which is always defined by the 
observer, but the main point of this is that the both objects have a clear 
relation to this observer's absolute, such a relation that it can be 
absolutely defined), they have covered equal distances in time. The other 
one just has done it "faster". However, they have both been perceivable, so 
they both must have remained within time, and the time has flown onward 
within both objects. Thus, no time travel has been detected.

Of course, time travel as defined by connotation, must be physically 
impossible. At least to the modern knowledge. It would disturb the 
stability of energy: energy can't cease to exist for a while, and then 
begin to exist again. May be that future physics prove otherwise, but the

+Austin Geary There has been a lot of discussion about how motion must be 
determined. Relativity explains motion as relative motion to other objects. 
This is of course a bit problematic, because we could always argue about 
the relative directions. If you have water in a bucket, and you start 
spining the bucket, you'll see that:
1. The bucket is still, and the water is still. Neither move relatively.
2. The bucket starts spinning, but the water is still still. Now the bucket 
moves relatively to the water.
3. The water gains speed. Both the bucket and the water spin with the same 
speed. Thus, they have no relative speed. The water's edge rises up, and 
the middle of the surface goes lower. You know that.
4.We start to slow down. The bucket is still, but the water spins. The 
bucket moves relatively to the water, and the water's edge is still higher 
than the middle.
5. Both stop, water surface normal, no relative speed.

Why does the water's surface change? It's not because of the movement, 
because the movement is relative. What if it's relative to Earth? Why would 
the water care about the Earth? Not to mention that the Earth spins too, 
and it doesn't matter to which direction you spin the bucket, the result is 
the exact same.

This is why we must define something as an absolute space (or absolute 
space-time). This means that we can define specific points in the absolute 
space-time, and movement is relative to these. This of course means that 
the matter around these points doesn't matter. 

The defined points in absolute space time are completely still. We could 
define the points so that the distance between each closest points is 
always 1m. This means that their distance will always be 1m, regardless of 
what happens around them. They are not bound to London's map or anything 
else.

When the space enlarges, the distance of these points remains at 1m. This 
is because the metre itself becomes relatively longer. This is why we 
perceive the universe to enlarge. If we take to distant galaxies that have 
no absolute speed relative to one another. This means that they are both 
still. Even so, we would still perceive the other galaxy as going away, 
because the space between the two galaxies expands. This means that the two 
galaxies have relative speed, but would that mean that the other one's 
clock would run faster? No, because their absolute speed, their speed which 
is relative only to the absolute space-time, is the same, zero.

 Yes, yes (mostly), yes, and yes.

Two people in the same place at the same time moving along at the same rate 
and direction are in the same reference frame, which means that time moves 
at the same rate for them (though, really, they'd have to be literally in 
the same place standing within one another to truly have the same reference 
frame, but it's close enough).  If they looked at things outside of their 
reference frame, they would see some sort of dilation effect, either 
spatial, temporal, or both (yes, not only does time distort but space 
distorts as well, things get shorter along the direction of travel).  
Similarly, observers outside their frame of reference looking at them would 
see dilation effects on them, usually the inverse of what the other would 
see.

For instance, if you were traveling near the speed of light, everything 
passing by you would appear to smear out, and time outside of you would 
also appear to be going much faster than it should be, though everything 
would seem normal to you otherwise, whereas people looking at you from 
outside would see you squished up along the direction of travel and your 
time would appear to be moving much slower to them.

comments.text:
+Uuni
Sorry, I guess I missinterpreted that, when you spoke of reversed effect.

The point still stands though, that your clock (from the standpoint of an 
non-moving observer) ticks slower if you travel faster, not the other way 
around.

The answer to your question is not that simple really.

First of, you can't simply say, that "a clock ticks slower".
You always have to add a frame of reference. For example "the clock in the 
spaceship ticks slower than the clock on earth as seen by the observers on 
earth".

As such, it is not possible to see another clock ticking faster than you 
own (at least in special relativity), because movement is relative.
Even though you might say, that the spaceship is moving away from earth it 
would be equally true to say, that earth is moving away from the spaceship, 
meaning, viewed from the spaceship, clocks on earth would tick slower than 
those on the spaceship,
while earthbound observers would see the clocks on the spaceship ticking 
slower than their own.

I know, that this seems pretty impossible, especially since after the 
flight, you can still determine that less time passed inside of the 
highspeed spaceship than on earth.
It is explainable though, if you look at it with the relativity of 
simultaneity in mind,
which is a different topic all on it's own.

Seeing a clock speeding up in comparision to your own is an entirely 
different thing though.
It is possible, if the relative speed between two observers gets smaller.
In that case, both observers see the clock of the other observer "speed up",
until the point where the relative speed becomes zero and each observer
sees the own clock tick at the same speed as the clock of the other 
observer.

As you've probably gathered, all of this isn't that easy to understand, 
because most of it is pretty counterintuitive, so I've added a simplified 
to long didn't read:

TL;DR:
It is not possible to see the clock of some one else tick slower than your 
own.
It is however possible to see the clock of some one else speed up in 
comparision to your own, if he is slowing down.

captions.text:
Have you ever daydreamed
about traveling through time,

perhaps fast forward in the centuries
and seeing the distant future?
Well, time travel is possible,
and what's more, it's already been done.
Meet Sergei Krikalev,

the greatest time traveler
in human history.
This Russian cosmonaut holds the record

for the most amount of time
spent orbiting our planet,

a total of 803 days,
9 hours, and 39 minutes.
During his stay in space,
he time traveled into his own future
by 0.02 seconds.
Traveling at 17,500 miles an hour,

he experienced an effect
known as time dilation,
and one day the same effect

might make significant time travel
to the future commonplace.

To see why moving faster through space
affects passage of time,
we need to go back to the 1880s,
when two American scientists,
Albert Michelson and Edward Morley,

were trying to measure the effect
of the Earth's movement around the Sun
on the speed of light.

When a beam of light was moving
in the same direction as the Earth,
they expected the light to travel faster.

And when the Earth was moving
in the opposite direction,
they expected it to go slower.
But they found something very curious.

The speed of light remained the same
no matter what the Earth was doing.

Two decades later,
Albert Einstein was thinking

about the consequences
of that never-changing speed of light.
And it was his conclusions,

formulated in the theory
of special relativity,

that opened the door
into the world of time travel.
Imagine a man named Jack,

standing in the middle
of a train carriage,
traveling at a steady speed.

Jack's bored and starts bouncing
a ball up and down.

What would Jill, standing on the platform,
see through the window
as the train whistles through?

Well, between Jack dropping the ball
and catching it again,

Jill would have seen him move
slightly further down the track,

resulting in her seeing the ball
follow a triangular path.

This means Jill sees the ball
travel further than Jack does
in the same time period.

And because speed
is distance divided by time,
Jill actually sees the ball move faster.

But what if Jack's bouncing ball
is replaced with two mirrors
which bounce a beam of light between them?
Jack still sees the beam dropping down

and Jill still sees the light beam
travel a longer distance,

except this time Jack and Jill
cannot disagree on the speed

because the speed of light
remains the same no matter what.

And if the speed is the same
while the distance is different,

this means the time taken
will be different as well.

Thus, time must tick at different rates
for people moving relative to each other.

Imagine that Jack and Jill
have highly accurate watches

that they synchronize
before Jack boards the train.

During the experiment,
Jack and Jill would each see
their own watch ticking normally.

But if they meet up again later
to compare watches,

less time would have
elapsed on Jack's watch,

balancing the fact that Jill saw
the light move further.
This idea may sound crazy,
but like any good scientific theory,
it can be tested.
In the 1970s, scientists boarded a plane
with some super-accurate atomic clocks

that were synchronized
with some others left on the ground.

After the plane had
flown around the world,

the clocks on board
showed a different time
from those left behind.

Of course, at the speed
of trains and planes,
the effect is minuscule.

But the faster you go,
the more time dilates.

For astronauts orbiting
the Earth for 800 days,
it starts to add up.

But what affects humans
also affects machines.

Satellites of the global
positioning system
are also hurdling around the Earth
at thousands of miles an hour.
So, time dilation kicks in here, too.

In fact, their speed causes
the atomic clocks on board
to disagree with clocks on the ground
by seven millionths of a second daily.
Left uncorrected,
this would cause GPS to lose accuracy
by a few kilometers each day.

So, what does all this have
to do with time travel
to the far, distant future?

Well, the faster you go,
the greater the effect of time dilation.
If you could travel really close
to the speed of light, say 99.9999%,
on a round-trip through space
for what seemed to you like ten years,
you'd actually return to Earth
around the year 9000.

Who knows what you'd see
when you returned?!
Humanity merged with machines,

extinct due to climate change
or asteroid impact,
or inhabiting a permanent colony on Mars.
But the trouble is,

getting heavy things like people,
not to mention space ships,

up to such speeds requires
unimaginable amounts of energy.

It already takes enormous
particle accelerators
like the Large Hadron Collider

to accelerate tiny subatomic particles
to close to light speed.

But one day, if we can develop the tools
to accelerate ourselves to similar speeds,
then we may regularly send time travelers
into the future,

bringing with them tales
of a long, forgotten past.
